update.description:
added `dot_generator` executable that parses an sdf world file and prints out a dot graph

The code does manual string parsing as opposed to using the sdformat parser mainly because it needs the tile URI string which does not seem to be accessible through the sdformat parser. So one limitation to keep in mind is that it does filter out `<include>` blocks that are commented out, i.e. it sees them as another model that’s included.

It also reuses part of the connection validator code for identifying valid connections .

example usage:

```
$ <path_to_subt_install_dir>/share/subt_ign/dot_generator simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot
```

‌
update.title: Generate DOT from SDF

content.html: just saw in the tile_tsv script that there’s also a special check for base station tile when assigning edge cost so the change is good

content.html: thanks for fix, the changes look good to me!

content.html: @Nate Koenig it looks like you also modified the dot_generator.cc to reflect my comments, correct?

content.html: I made a number of cost changes in order to bring the output of this DOT generator inline with the existing DOT files. @Ian Chen , could you confirm these changes?

content.html: I changed the cost of connections to the base_station to 1. bba8763 I assume that is the correct thing to do.

update.description:
added `dot_generator` executable that parses an sdf world file and prints out a dot graph

The code does manual string parsing as opposed to using the sdformat parser mainly because it needs the tile URI string which does not seem to be accessible through the sdformat parser. So one limitation to keep in mind is that it does filter out `<include>` blocks that are commented out, i.e. it sees them as another model that’s included.

It also reuses part of the connection validator code for identifying valid connections .

example usage:

```
$ <path_to_subt_install_dir>/share/subt_ign/dot_generator simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot
```

‌
update.title: Generate DOT from SDF

content.raw: For #2, I found that the existing DOT files used vertex numbers that matched the tile names. I changed the `dot_generator` to match so that diffs are easier to parse. 63ddfb5
content.html: For #2, I found that the existing DOT files used vertex numbers that matched the tile names. I changed the dot_generator to match so that diffs are easier to parse. 63ddfb5

content.raw: I changed the cost of the `Stairwell Platform *` tiles in `ConnectionHelper` to match the cost in `tile_tsv.py`. 73075a0
content.html: I changed the cost of the Stairwell Platform * tiles in ConnectionHelper to match the cost in tile_tsv.py. 73075a0

update.title: Generate DOT from SDF

content.raw:
I was looking at diffs between the DOT files generated by this program and existing DOT files.

1. Should the base station connection have a cost/label of 1? Right now this generator uses a label of 3.
2. I don't think this matters, but the existing DOT files skip vertex numbers. The skips don't seem consistent. I often see 6, 10, 12, 28 skipped.
3. Compare the existing`simple_urban_01.dot`  with the DOT file generated by `dot_generator`. There are a few edges with a cost of 6 that cost 3 in existing DOT files.
content.html:
I was looking at diffs between the DOT files generated by this program and existing DOT files.

  1. Should the base station connection have a cost/label of 1? Right now this generator uses a label of 3.
  2. I don't think this matters, but the existing DOT files skip vertex numbers. The skips don't seem consistent. I often see 6, 10, 12, 28 skipped.
  3. Compare the existingsimple_urban_01.dot with the DOT file generated by dot_generator. There are a few edges with a cost of 6 that cost 3 in existing DOT files.

update.title: Generate DOT from SDF

content.raw:
As a heads up, I had to give the full path to the `.sdf` file when running the example usage command:

```
./install/subt_ign/share/subt_ign/dot_generator install/subt_ign/share/subt_ign/worlds/simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot
```

if I was not in the `subt_ign/worlds` directory and tried to run the command without specifying the full path, this is the output:

```
adl@osrf:~/Downloads/test$ ./install/subt_ign/share/subt_ign/dot_generator simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot
Failed to read file simple_cave_01.sdf
```

‌
content.html:
As a heads up, I had to give the full path to the .sdf file when running the example usage command:

./install/subt_ign/share/subt_ign/dot_generator install/subt_ign/share/subt_ign/worlds/simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot

if I was not in the subt_ign/worlds directory and tried to run the command without specifying the full path, this is the output:

adl@osrf:~/Downloads/test$ ./install/subt_ign/share/subt_ign/dot_generator simple_cave_01.sdf > simple_cave_01.dot
Failed to read file simple_cave_01.sdf

‌

content.raw: should there be a few tests written for the dot\_generator?
content.html: should there be a few tests written for the dot_generator?

content.raw:
I noticed a few issues from the [pipeline](#!/osrf/subt/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/2036):

```
[src/dot_generator.cc:29]: (performance) Function parameter '_key' should be passed by reference.
[src/dot_generator.cc:52]: (performance) Function parameter '_key' should be passed by reference.
./src/dot_generator.cc:112:  Extra space before last semicolon. If this should be an empty statement, use {} instead.  [whitespace/semicolon] [5]
./src/ConnectionHelper.cc:200:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
```

do these need to be addressed?
content.html:
I noticed a few issues from the pipeline:

[src/dot_generator.cc:29]: (performance) Function parameter '_key' should be passed by reference.
[src/dot_generator.cc:52]: (performance) Function parameter '_key' should be passed by reference.
./src/dot_generator.cc:112:  Extra space before last semicolon. If this should be an empty statement, use {} instead.  [whitespace/semicolon] [5]
./src/ConnectionHelper.cc:200:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]

do these need to be addressed?
